1.target_gt: To those who go in bliss, the dharmakāya they possess, and all their heirs, To all those worthy of respect, I reverently bow.

Grammar:
- མངའ་ (possess) connects བདེ་གཤེགས་ to ཆོས་ཀྱི་སྐུ་
- བཅས་དང་ (together with) links the first phrase to the second line
- ཀུན་ལའང་ (to all) modifies ཕྱག་འོས་
- ཏེ་ (and) connects this verse to what follows

<t>The Well-gone Ones who possess the dharmakāya, together with [their] heirs, and</t>
<t>To all those worthy of respect, I respectfully bow.</t>

Note: བདེ་གཤེགས་ (Well-gone One) is an epithet for buddhas.
01_zero_shot_translation.translation: The Well-gone Ones who possess the dharmakāya, together with [their] heirs, and To all those worthy of respect, I respectfully bow.

<t>And I do not possess expertise in poetic composition.</t>

- The structure uses negatives (མ་ and མེད་) to emphasize humility
- སྡེབ་སྦྱོར་ refers specifically to the art of poetic meter and composition in Sanskrit and Tibetan literature
01_zero_shot_translation.translation: There is nothing expressed here that has not occurred previously, And I do not possess expertise in poetic composition.

I do not possess the skill of a master of poetic composition.

This type of aspiration is characteristic of the mind training (བློ་སྦྱོང་) tradition in Tibetan Buddhism.

162.target_gt: Just as all the Buddhas of the past Have brought forth the awakened mind, And in the precepts of the Bodhisattvas Step-by-step abode and trained, Likewise, for the benefit of beings, I will bring to birth the awakened mind, And in those precepts, step-by-step, I will abide and train myself.

Technical note: This verse begins the formal generation of bodhicitta (བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་) by following the example of previous Buddhas. The phrase རིམ་བཞིན་གནས་པ་ (abided gradually) refers to the progressive stages of bodhisattva training. The use of honorific terms (ཐུགས་, བགྱི་) shows respect for the Buddhas and elevates the act of generating bodhicitta. This verse is often recited as part of formal bodhicitta generation ceremonies in Tibetan Buddhism.

The reference to ཡི་དྭགས་ (hungry ghosts) represents a lower realm of rebirth in Buddhist cosmology. The phrase བླ་ན་མེད་པའི་བདེ་བ་ (unsurpassed happiness) likely refers to enlightenment or Buddhahood. Key terms: སྦྲང་བུ་ (fly), ཤ་སྦྲང་ (horsefly), བུང་བ་ (bee), སྲིན་བུ་ (insect)

Key terms: བརྩོན་པ་ (diligence), སྟོབས་ (strength), བྱང་ཆུབ་ (bodhi), བླ་མེད་ (unsurpassed)

1583.target_gt: This completes the Bodhisattvacharyavatara, The Way of the Bodhisattva, which was composed by the master Shāntideva.

01_zero_shot_translation.output:
Key terms:
བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔའ་ (bodhisattva), སྤྱོད་པ་ (conduct), འཇུག་པ་ (entering), སློབ་དཔོན་ (ācārya), མཛད་པ་ (composed), རྫོགས་སོ་ (completed)

Grammar:
- Genitive particle འི་ connecting བྱང་ཆུབ་སེམས་དཔ and སྤྱོད་པ
- Agentive particle ས་ indicating Śāntideva as the author

<t>The "Entering the Conduct of the Bodhisattvas," composed by Ācārya Śāntideva, is completed.</t>

Note: This appears to be a colophon indicating the end of the text "Bodhicaryāvatāra" by Śāntideva.
01_zero_shot_translation.translation: The "Entering the Conduct of the Bodhisattvas," composed by Ācārya Śāntideva, is completed.

02_simple_zero_shot_translation.output:
Here is my attempt at translating that Tibetan Buddhist passage into English:

<t>The Bodhisattvacharyavatara (Guide to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life) composed by Master Shantideva is complete.</t>
02_simple_zero_shot_translation.translation: The Bodhisattvacharyavatara (Guide to the Bodhisattva's Way of Life) composed by Master Shantideva is complete.

1584.target_gt: The text was translated, edited, and finalized in Tibetan on the basis of a manuscript from Kashmir by the Indian scholar Sarvajñādeva and the monk, translator, and editor Kawa Peltsek.

01_zero_shot_translation.output:
Key terms:
རྒྱ་གར་ (India), མཁན་པོ་ (abbot), ཞུ་ཆེན་ (great editor), ལོ་ཙཱ་བ་ (translator), བནྡེ་ (monk), ཁ་ཆེ་ (Kashmir), དཔེ་ (text), བསྒྱུར་ (translate), ཞུས་ (edit), གཏན་ལ་ཕབ་ (establish)

Grammar:
- Instrumental case (གྱིས) indicating agents
- Ablative case (ལས) indicating source
- Connective (ཅིང་) joining actions

<t>The Indian abbot Sarvajñādeva and the great editor-translator Bandé Peltsek translated [this text] from a Kashmiri exemplar, edited [it], and established [the final version].</t>

Note: 
- སརྦ་ཛྙཱ་དེ་བ་ (Sarvajñādeva) and དཔལ་བརྩེགས་ (Peltsek) are proper names left untranslated
- བནྡེ་ (Bandé) is an honorific title for a monk
01_zero_shot_translation.translation: The Indian abbot Sarvajñādeva and the great editor-translator Bandé Peltsek translated [this text] from a Kashmiri exemplar, edited [it], and established [the final version].

02_simple_zero_shot_translation.output:
Here is my attempt at translating the Tibetan passage into English:

<t>
The Indian abbot Sarvajñadeva and the great translator Bandé Peltsek translated and edited this from the Kashmiri text, revising and finalizing it.
</t>
02_simple_zero_shot_translation.translation: The Indian abbot Sarvajñadeva and the great translator Bandé Peltsek translated and edited this from the Kashmiri text, revising and finalizing it.

1585.target_gt: At a later time, this version was revised and finalized in accordance with the version from Magadha, together with its commentary, by the Indian scholar Dharmashrībhadra and the Tibetan monks, translators and editors, Rinchen Zangpo and Shākya Lodrö.

01_zero_shot_translation.output:
Key terms:
སླད་ཀྱི་ (later), མཁན་པོ་ (abbot), ཞུ་ཆེན་ (great translator), ལོ་ཙཱ་བ་ (translator), བནྡེ་ (monk), ཡུལ་དབུས་ (central region), དཔེ་ (text), འགྲེལ་པ་ (commentary), བཅོས་ (revised), བསྒྱུར་ (translated), གཏན་ལ་ཕབ་ (established)

<t>Later, the Indian abbot Dharmaśrībhadra, together with the great translators, the monk Rinchen Zangpo and Śākya Lodrö, revised and translated [this text], establishing [it] in accordance with the texts and commentaries from the central region.</t>

Notes:
- "སླད་ཀྱི་" indicates this is a later revision or translation.
- "ཞུ་ཆེན་གྱི་ལོ་ཙཱ་བ་" refers to highly skilled translators.
- "ཡུལ་དབུས་" likely refers to central India, the source of authoritative Buddhist texts.
- The final verb string "བཅོས་ཤིང་བསྒྱུར་ཏེ་གཏན་ལ་ཕབ་པ" indicates a process of revising, translating, and establishing an authoritative version.
01_zero_shot_translation.translation: Later, the Indian abbot Dharmaśrībhadra, together with the great translators, the monk Rinchen Zangpo and Śākya Lodrö, revised and translated [this text], establishing [it] in accordance with the texts and commentaries from the central region.

02_simple_zero_shot_translation.output:
Here is my attempt at translating the Tibetan passage into English:

<t>
Later, the Indian abbot Dharmasribhadra, along with the great translator Bande Rinchen Zangpo and Shakya Lodro, revised and translated [this text] in accordance with the central [Indian] version and commentary, establishing the definitive version.
</t>
02_simple_zero_shot_translation.translation: Later, the Indian abbot Dharmasribhadra, along with the great translator Bande Rinchen Zangpo and Shakya Lodro, revised and translated [this text] in accordance with the central [Indian] version and commentary, establishing the definitive version.

1586.target_gt: Still later, it was again revised and finalized by the Indian scholar Sumatikīrti and the monk, translator, and editor Ngok Loden Sherab.

01_zero_shot_translation.output:
Key terms:
ཡང་དུས་ཕྱིས་ (later time), མཁན་པོ་ (abbot), ཞུ་ཆེན་ (great editor), ལོ་ཙཱ་བ་ (translator), དགེ་སློང་ (bhikṣu), དག་པར་བཅོས་ (corrected), བསྒྱུར་ (translated), གཏན་ལ་ཕབ་ (established)

<t>Later, the Indian abbot Sumatikīrti and the great editor-translator, the bhikṣu Loden Sherab, corrected, translated, and established [this text].</t>

Notes:
- སུ་མ་ཏི་ཀཱིརྟི་ is the Sanskrit name Sumatikīrti
- བློ་ལྡན་ཤེས་རབ་ is the Tibetan name Loden Sherab
- The final ་པའོ།།།། indicates the conclusion of a text or section
01_zero_shot_translation.translation: Later, the Indian abbot Sumatikīrti and the great editor-translator, the bhikṣu Loden Sherab, corrected, translated, and established [this text].

02_simple_zero_shot_translation.output:

Later, the Indian abbot Sumatikīrti and the great translator Lotsawa Gelong Loden Sherab carefully edited, translated, and finalized [this text].
</t>
02_simple_zero_shot_translation.translation: Later, the Indian abbot Sumatikīrti and the great translator Lotsawa Gelong Loden Sherab carefully edited, translated, and finalized [this text].
